awd_titl_txt: Determining the source of muscle power for suction feeding in ray-finned fishes
awd_abstract_narration:
Most fish capture food by sucking it into their mouths, and successful suction feeding is both fast and forceful. Speed and force combined require high power from muscles, but where does all of that muscle power come from? Fish head muscles are small, but the body muscles are large. Do fish transfer power from their bodies to their heads, similar to the way baseball pitchers transfer power from their legs and core to their throwing arms? Recent developments in 3D X-ray imaging have made it possible to measure power directly, and this project will use the new technology, XROMM (X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology), to study fish with diverse body forms and feeding habits. The significance of this research is a new framework for understanding the structure and function of body and head muscles in 30,000 species of fish (half of all vertebrate species), and the results will impact ongoing research in numerous labs worldwide studying the biomechanics, ecology and evolution of suction feeding. This project will engage children from the Providence RI public schools in an after-school Marine Biology Science Camp, providing an opportunity to do fun science projects with students from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. This project will develop a new technology, VROMM (Video Reconstruction of Moving Morphology), with similar capabilities as XROMM but with video cameras instead of expensive X-ray machines. VROMM will accelerate research by making the technology more widely available and advance US economic competiveness through technological innovation.

A recent study of largemouth bass showed that axial muscles provide more than 95% of the power for high-performance suction feeding, but these results so far come from just one species. Might axial muscles be the main source of suction power in most fishes? The goal of this project is to measure the power capacity of cranial and axial musculature relative to the power required for suction feeding in six species of fishes with different body forms and distant phylogenetic relationships to largemouth bass. XROMM combined with the dynamic endocast method will be used to measure instantaneous rate of buccal volume change, and a pressure transducer will be used to measure buccal pressure. Pressure multiplied by the rate of volume change will yield instantaneous suction power. Optimal muscle power capacity (Popt) will be calculated from muscle mass and the maximum power produced by fish muscle, which assumes shortening at the optimal velocity. Actual muscle velocity will be measured with XROMM and fluoromicrometry, and velocity-corrected power capacity (Pvc) calculated. The Pvc for cranial and axial muscles will be compared to the power required for suction feeding to determine the maximum power that cranial muscles can contribute, and therefore the minimum power that axial muscles must be contributing. These results may provide a new framework for studying suction feeding, in which the anatomy, biomechanics, and evolution of the axial musculoskeletal system should be studied as the power source for feeding, or at least as compromises between the needs of swimming and feeding.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Suction feeding is used by over 30,000 species of ray-finned fishes to catch their food. This fast and forceful behaviour requires high power, at least some of which was known to come from the body muscles immediately behind the head. But at least one fish (largemouth bass) generated over 95% of suction feeding power with its body muscles. If such body-powered feeding is widespread in fishes, this suggests a new framework for studying the anatomy, biomechanics, and evolution of suction feeding itself and the skeleton and muscles of the body. However, it is only with the recent development of X-ray Reconstruction of Moving Morphology (XROMM) combined with the dynamic endocast method that it is possible to measure the power required for suction feeding.

 

We collected x-ray video, pressure, and 3D anatomy data from 5 fish species representing a wide range of body shapes: bluegill sunfish (n=2), channel catfish (n=3), common carp (n=3), royal knifefish (n=3), and Polypterus (n=2). For sunfish, catfish, and knifefish, we measured suction power by recording the pressure inside the mouth and the change in mouth volume with XROMM animations and a dynamic digital endocast. Muscle size and shortening during suction feeding were also measured to estimate the power capacity of the head and body muscles. We compared the suction power and muscle power capacity to determine if body muscles are the dominant source of suction power, and how much of these muscles contribute to feeding.

 

Like bass, all 3 species relied on body muscles to generate 90-99% of the power for the high-performance suction feeding. Most fish used over 80% of the body muscles to generate this power, except for channel catfish. This species does not use head elevation or dorsal body muscle shortening, so suction power was only generated by the ventral (hypaxial) body muscles. Our results suggest body-powered suction feeding is widespread, establishing a new framework for the biomechanics and physiology of suction feeding in ray-finned fishes. This framework shows the body structures have dual roles in feeding and swimming and highlights the importance of studying mechanical and evolutionary interactions between the head and body.

 

In contrast, the role of the largest head muscle, the sternohyoideus, varied among species. In largemouth bass, the sternohyoideus maintains a constant length, acting like a ligament to transmit power from the body muscles to the feeding apparatus. But in catfish, sunfish, and knifefish, the sternohyoideus shortens to generate power during suction feeding. The power capacity of the sternohyoideus may be sufficient to power the lowest-performance strikes. We showed the sternohyoideus can both generate and transmit power, leading to new questions about how and why its function varies.

 

While all our study species relied on body muscles to power feeding, the magnitude of suction power varied considerably, even after accounting for body size and muscle mass. This variation may be linked to body shape, as the species with the most powerful strikes per unit muscle mass (sunfish and knifefish) both have laterally compressed deep bodies, with tall body muscles and ventrally curved vertebral columns. We also found fish can generate high power strikes through different mechanisms: increasing the rate of volume change, the magnitude of intraoral pressure, or both.

 

Broader Impacts

This project provided research training for undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and a technician, supported K-12 education, increased participation of underrepresented groups, and developed scientific infrastructure. Throughout the project, 12 undergraduate students, 7 graduate students, and 2 postdoctoral researchers gained research training in XROMM and digital visualization. Participation of underrepresented groups was increased through training for a Hispanic doctoral student, Yordano Jimenez, and an African-American doctoral student, J.J. Lomax. Additionally, our team ran a Marine Biology Science Club at a public high school with a student body that is 61% Hispanic and 25% African American with 75% qualifying for free or reduced-price lunch. Most of the student-contact hours were led by Yordano and J.J. and included collaboration and research experience for math and science teachers. Our project contributed to scientific infrastructure through the development and validation of a dynamic digital endocast tool and the development of Video Reconstruction of Moving Morphology (VROMM), i.e., XROMM without the need for X-ray machines.
